etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French quintaine, perhaps based on Latin quintana, a street in a Roman camp separating the fifth and sixth maniples, where military exercises were performed (from quintus ‘fifth’)

definitions: a post set up as a mark in tilting with a lance, typically with a sandbag attached that would swing around and strike an unsuccessful tilter.
shortDefinitions: post set up as mark in tilting with lance

definitions: the medieval military exercise of tilting at a quintain.
shortDefinitions: medieval military exercise of tilting at quintain
